newsitem.title: TURKEY: Turkish financial markets closed for holiday.
newsitem.headline: Turkish financial markets closed for holiday.

text.p: Turkish financial markets were closed on Monday for the public Youth and Sport Day holiday.

On Friday, Istanbul shares fell in profit-taking after a 5.43 percent surge a day earlier, brokers said. Sentiment was also depressed by anticipation of a government censure motion debate expected to be held in parliament this week, they said.
Four opposition parties submitted a censure motion last week to topple Islamist Prime Minister Necmettin Erbakan's coalition.

The IMKB National-100 fell 1.52 percent, or 23 points, to 1,492. The index soared more than eight percent in the previous three days on speculation about a new secularist alliance excluding the ruling Islamists.
Bond yields eased back from early gains on Friday to just over 100 percent after the Treasury announced a public offering of T-bills for May 21 when it faces a 61 trillion lira bond redemption.
The Turkish lira weakened to 137,700 per dollar on Friday from a previous close of 136,950.
The markets will reopen on Tuesday.
